13©y2) Crystal parameters    [C54H52F24N12P4], M = 1448.95, monoclinic, space group P1 21/c1, a = 8.2911(5) ?, b = 28.5890(18) ?, c = 28.0267(19) ?, Ï« = 90¡« , ÉÇ = 90.912(3)¡« , ÎÛ = 90¡« , V = 6642.4(7) ?3, Z = 4, T = 193 K, ÀÏcalc = 1.449 mg/m3, Ã×(GaK Ï«) = 1.337 mm-1. A total of 87775 reflections were collected, of which 12715 were unique ( Rint = 0.1176). Final R1 (I > 2¿¼(I)) = 0.1350 and wR 2 = 0.3022. The structure was solved by direct method and different Fourier syntheses. Using Olex2, the structure was solved with the ShelXT structure solution program using Intrinsic Phasing and refined with the ShelXL refinement package using Least Squares minimizat ion. CCDC number: 2125354.

3©y32+?2Br? : A solution of pyridin -4-ylhydrazine (546 mg, 5 mmol) in 100 mL of acetone was heated to reflux overnight. 1,4 -bis(bromomethyl)benzene (264 mg, 1 mmol) was then added to the reaction mixture. The reaction was heated at reflux for 24 h. The precipitate wa s collected via filtration and washed with hot acetone (3 ¨G  20 mL), yielding pure 32+?2Br? (449 mg, 80 %) as a yellow powder. 32+?2Br? was characterized by recording its 1H NMR spectrum (Figure S1 , S5), 13C NMR spectrum (Figure S2 , S6), HSQC spectrum (Figure S3 , S7), HMBC spectrum (Figure S4 , S8), as well as by means of mass spectrometry (Figure S9). 1H NMR  (500 MHz, DMSO -d6): Ñ´ (ppm):  11.04 (s, 2H), 8.50 (d, J = 7 Hz, 2H), 8.43 (d, J = 7 Hz, 2H), 7.46 (s, 4H), 7.39 (d, J = 9 Hz, 2H), 7.32 (d, J = 2 Hz, 2H), 5.47 (s, 4H), 2.04 (s, 13H). 13C NMR  (125 MHz, DMSO -d6): Ñ´ (ppm): 158.0, 154.7, 144.4, 143. 2, 136.5, 129. 3, 109.5, 107.4, 59.9, 25.7, 18. 7. HRMS : m/z calculated for C24H30N62+ ([3]2+): 201.1260; found: 201.1273.

5©y42+?2Br?: Isoquinoline -5-carbaldehyde (786 mg, 5 mmol) and 1,4 -bis(bromomethyl)benzene (264 mg, 1 mmol) were dissolved in 100 mL of acetonitrile and heated at reflux for 24 hours. 7©yM4+?4PF 6?: The p recursors 32+?2Br? (112 mg, 0.2 mmol) and 42+?2Br?(115 mg, 0.2 mmol) were combined in 80 mL of water. Concentrated HCl (0.8 mL) was then added.

8©yThe reaction mixture was heated at 70 ¡Í for 12 h. After cooling, excess of NH 4+?PF6? was added until no further precipitation was observed. 9©yComplex M4+?4NO 3? was obtained via counterion exchange by adding an excess of TBA+NO 3? into a solution of M4+?4PF 6? in acetonitrile , followed by filtration to collect the corresponding precipitates . M4+?4NO 3? was characterized by recording its 1H NMR S6  spectrum (Figure S 29), 1H-1H COSY spectrum (Figure S 30), 1H-1H NOESY spectrum (Figure S 31), and mass spectrometry (Figure S 32).

Materials and General Methods  All reagents and solvents were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. Manipulations were performed under a normal atmosphere unless otherwise indicated. Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra were recorded at ambient tem perature using Bruker A V ANCE III 400/500 and Agilent DD2 600 spectrometers, with working frequencies of 400/500/600 and 100/125/150 MHz for 1H and 13C, respectively. Chemical shifts are reported in ppm relative to the residual internal non -deuterated solve nt signals (D 2O: Ñ´ = 4.79 ppm, DMSO -d6: Ñ´ = 2.50 ppm, CD 3CN: Ñ´ = 1.94 ppm). High -resolution mass spectra (HRMS) were recorded on a Fourier transform ion cyclotron resonance mass spectrometry (FT -ICR MS). X -ray crystallographic data were collected on a Bruk er D8 Venture diffractometer.
